segments.text: Tony, I need to talk to you about the incident yesterday with the plumbing crew.
Yeah, I figured you'd want to discuss that. Things got heated.
Heated is putting it mildly. I heard you yelled at their foreman in front of the whole crew. That's not how we operate.
James, they were three hours late and didn't call. That's the third time this month. We had electricians waiting on them.
I get it. You're frustrated. I'm frustrated too. But publicly humiliating their foreman doesn't solve anything. It makes things worse.
So what, I'm just supposed to smile and say thanks for showing up?
No. You pull him aside, one-on-one, and have a professional conversation. Then you document it and escalate to me if needed.
I hear you. I lost my cool. I should've handled it differently.
I appreciate you owning that. Now you need to apologize to him. Today. And we'll have a meeting with their company owner to address the pattern.
Apologize? James, he's the one who keeps screwing up our schedule!
Yes, and we'll address that through proper channels. But you yelled at him. That was wrong, regardless of what he did. Leaders apologize when they're wrong.
Alright. I'll talk to him this morning.
Good. And Tony, I know you care about this project. That's why you got upset. But we have to maintain professional standards.
I know you will. Now let's talk about the plumbing company. I'm calling their owner today. This pattern needs to stop or we find a replacement.
Thank you. That's all I wanted - for someone to take this seriously.

environment.background_sounds: quiet office, door closed, occasional paper rustling
